intro_text: The apprentices emerge into a predawn world hushed and smothered in a fresh blanket of snow! app1 and app2 tear off into the territory near camp, looking to play.
decline_text: Their mentors are already up for the day, and call them back. There'll be time to play later.

success_outcomes.text: The snow seems to have melted and refrozen during the night, and app1 darts lightly over the top of the thin crust. app2 follows them, only to immediately hear a crack and sink up to their ear tips in the fluffy stuff. Teasingly, app1 runs around near them, and it turns into a game of app2 romping through the snow trying to catch them.

app1 finds a snowdrift, and over the course of an hour them and app2 turn it into a very respectable snow den, complete with short entrance tunnel. They're debating what to call the camp of their little Clan when their mentors arrive, congratulating them on running an excellent wilderness survival session without supervision.

After a while romping around in the heavy snow, app1 complains of the cold seeping into their fur. s_c digs a little hollow, and invites them in to curl up with them. Strictly for warmth purposes of course. They both stay there as the sun rises. Strictly for warmth.

fail_outcomes.text: The apprentices find a promising looking patch of fresh snow, only to find it conceals an old dirtplace trench underneath. Not only does it stink, but they now have to clean it up and hide the fact that they disturbed it in the first place! It leaves the both of them irritated and stressed.
As they play in the snow, app1 falls over themselves embarrassingly, and suddenly decides they remember that they have other things they should be doing.
Both apprentices are back at camp in time for a normal day of training, but app1 has to confess their predawn adventure when they go to medicine cat den with a running nose.

intro_text: As they trudge through the snow, p_l spots a wolf pack round a kill in the distant valley below and calls app1 over.
decline_text: Thinking better of it, the cats try to hunt instead.

success_outcomes.text: It's a good opportunity to observe the dangerous predators from afar. app1 is surprised to watch them play, taking turns chasing and running from each other in a way that reminds them of the games they play with the other apprentices.

The wolves seem sleepy and full of what used to be an adult elk, massive and spread out in bits across the valley. A coyote approaches and steals a bite. When the wolves notice and run the scavenger down, wagging their tails as they tear it apart, the patrol watches silently, a grim reminder of what wolf packs are capable of.

s_c wants to point out not the wolves, but the ravens around them. Wolves mostly tolerate ravens at their kills because it helps them find prey. Long ago, that bargain was offered to the cats of the world, but they foolishly betrayed the ravens and took the birds for food instead, and since then only the dogs have benefited from allies in the sky.

fail_outcomes.text: One of the wolves peels off from the sleepy pack and starts ambling in the general direction of the cats, and p_l decides caution is wise. The patrol returns to camp without seeing anything more.

intro_text: Once, before myth and magic, there was only StarClan, and no Dark Forest. p_l gathers the patrol, talking in hushed meows of the birth of that place.
decline_text: A happier story, the cats ask, please. No one wants difficulty sleeping tonight.

success_outcomes.text: A dead warrior woke in StarClan, business unfinished and hate for the living in their heart. They brought ruin and destruction upon the living Clan - but c_n was not without allies. The other cats of StarClan leapt to battle and tore a hole in Silverpelt, casting out the traitor, condemning them to walk a path of decay and cruelty.

s_c can't help but be overly fascinated as p_l speaks about how a warrior was so powerful that they needed to tear a hole in silverpelt just to be able to stop them. s_c hopes to one day be that powerful.
s_c hears the tale and is inspired. {PRONOUN/s_c/subject/CAP} {VERB/s_c/wish/wishes} {PRONOUN/s_c/subject} {VERB/s_c/were/was} as strong as the cats in the tale.

At the end of the tale, s_c is inspired by how strong the outcast warrior is, but going against StarClan, that seems like a fool's errand. While s_c wouldn't mind being free of some of the rules of the Clan, {PRONOUN/s_c/subject} wouldn't dare go against StarClan.

fail_outcomes.text: r_c listens, shivering, as p_l describes the birth of the Dark Forest, the ancient, barely won battle between the good cats of the stars and the traitor amidst. {PRONOUN/r_c/subject/CAP} can't stop thinking about it in {PRONOUN/r_c/poss} nest that night, {PRONOUN/r_c/poss} sleep broken and uneasy.

At the end of the tale, p_l asks s_c what {PRONOUN/s_c/subject} {VERB/s_c/think/thinks}. s_c admits to not paying attention to some nursery story meant to scare kits.

intro_text: p_l gathers some of {PRONOUN/p_l/poss} Clanmates, huddled together for warmth, and offers a tale to take everyone's mind off of the storm raging outside camp.
decline_text: The wind, howling and vast, drowns p_l out. There'll be no stories today.

success_outcomes.text: Once, long ago, cats roamed without a Clan, fending for themselves. Leaf-bare picked off the elderly, weak, and unlucky one by one, eating away at them. But one cat opened the warmth of their heart to shelter others in their nest, pelts sharing heat, many paws making light work. They became the first Leader, and those cats the first Clan.

fail_outcomes.text: p_l tries, but the wind keeps creeping through the outer walls of the den, and the story is cut short as the cats work to repair it. r_c starts shivering halfway through the repair job.

history_text.reg_death: r_c died as a consequence of poor den construction, getting too cold in leaf-bare.
history_text.lead_death: as a consequence of poor den construction, getting too cold in leaf-bare

intro_text: Many seasons ago, p_l begins, there was born a powerful, Stars-gifted apprentice, one coveted by the Clans around them. Pulled in many directions, they could not keep the peace, as all demanded their time and skill.
decline_text: r_c doesn't have time to listen to p_l's story - {PRONOUN/r_c/subject} {VERB/r_c/apologize/apologizes}, but {PRONOUN/r_c/subject} rather {VERB/r_c/feel/feels} like that long dead overworked apprentice {PRONOUN/r_c/self}, right now!

success_outcomes.text: After moons of having their clan attacked and targeted, the apprentice raged, calling on their hidden power. They summoned a powerful snowstorm and created leafbare in their anger before fleeing the clans, never to return and never to walk the stars, their life and talents wasted by cruel petty fighting.

fail_outcomes.text: Rudely, r_c leaves in the middle of p_l's tale, stealing the momentum from it. p_l trails off, embarrassed.

s_c is so concerned with the health of the long dead apprentice it actually derails p_l's story, and {PRONOUN/p_l/subject} {VERB/p_l/have/has} to gently remind {PRONOUN/s_c/object} that this apprentice is long beyond helping.

intro_text: It's an old, important lesson. The apprentices are brought out to a valley, one side, steep, one shallow. The patrol settles on the shallow side, and the young cats are asked to study the clumped snow on the sharp wall across from them. Today, they will learn of avalanches.
decline_text: ...Or they would, if the valley wasn't so misted over it's barely possible to see the other side.

success_outcomes.text: The Mountain's Roar is not rage of blood and sinew, no anger of tooth or claw. It's unfeeling, unthinking, and uncaring, the deep rumble of the snowcaps themselves falling to their doom, p_l tells them. If they ever, ever feel their whiskers tremble with the noise, the only solution is to run - not down, but to the side, away from where the snow will flow. Do they understand?

Somberly, p_l lists the cats {PRONOUN/p_l/subject} {VERB/p_l/know/knows} who died to avalanche, who thought they were faster, who didn't heed the signs, who weren't cautious. Most of these cats were dead long before p_l was born, {PRONOUN/p_l/poss} knowledge of history going back gnerations, but this is what history is for. To learn from it.

There are tricks to it, p_l explains. Avalanches fall like sudden floods of water, or mud, but with unimaginable force. If you're caught, it's luck whether you survive. So don't get caught - run to the side of the slope, out of the path of the flow, horizonal, not tyring to race anything. Climb, climb anything. The tree will get swept away, but they might float.

p_l sees the apprentices nerves, and takes a moment to reassure them. The patrol is safe on this side of the valley. The important things to remember with avalanches is the warning sides, the trembling of snowpack under paw, the quiver in your whiskers that warns of danger.

fail_outcomes.text: The apprentices immediately start daring each other to go over and poke at the precarious snow. Highing disapproving, p_l cancels the lesson and sets them to cleaning the dirtplace instead.

The cats think they're safe on the other side of the valley. It's a well known spot for teaching, distant but with a view of the avalanche prone spot on the otherside, c_n cats have been here before. Surely they're safe. They are mistaken.
